snippet: A series of British governments have struggled with the question of expanding London’s airport capacity, but a weak economy makes the question more difficult.
abstract: British government grapples with the question of expanding London's airport capacity, but weak economy makes the question more difficult; Great Britain has long debated the issue, with no fewer than 10 government studies on the subject since 1946. Photo, Map (M)
lead_paragraph: LONDON -- As any pilot will tell you, landing an aircraft in a crosswind is a challenge. So, too, is deciding on where -- or whether -- to build a new airport runway. The political winds in Britain have shifted countless times over the decades on the question of expanding aviation capacity in and around London, which is already served by six commercial airports. No fewer than 10 government studies on the subject have been commissioned since 1946.

headline.main: A Sharp Debate in London Seeks to Address the State Of an Overworked Airport
